overview: From 2025-08-03 to 2025-08-10, ethereum-optimism/op-geth had 1 new PRs (0 merged), 0 new issues, and 4 active contributors.

topPRs.title: Calldata footprint block limit spike
topPRs.author: sebastianst
topPRs.body:
**Description**

Spike of calldata footprint block limit implementation.

Following the idea of [multidimenstional gas metering](https://ethresear.ch/t/a-practical-proposal-for-multidimensional-gas-metering/22668) (but without changing regular gas accounting), a new _calldata footprint_ resource is introduced. The calldata footprint is of the same scale as transaction gas. The total calldata footprint of a block is limited by the same gas limit as for regular gas. This has the effect that total calldata usage of a block is constrained, with the right parameters, more than by calldata (floor) gas usage. The _calldata footprint cost_ is comparable to the regular _calldata floor cost_, but higher values would be chosen.

Using the FastLZ-based estimated size of a transaction from Fjord, a transaction's calldata footprint is now simply `calldataFootprint = estimatedSize * calldataFootprintCost`. So it estimates the transaction's calldata impact on the DA batch it will be a part of, scaled to be comparable to gas, so it can be limited by the same block limit.

A block's _gas used_ field is now set to the maximum of the two resources, the total gas used of all transaction (as before), and the total calldata footprint of all transactions. This has the benefit that the EIP-1559 fee market now also takes total calldata footprint into account and the base fee reacts to calldata-heavy blocks.

An open question is whether we want to make the _calldata footprint cost_ a protocol constant, or configurable per chain via the `SystemConfig` L1 contract.

topContributors.summary: wlawt: Focused on providing feedback across pull requests this week, conducting 10 reviews and leaving one additional comment.

leopoldjoy: This week, leopoldjoy focused on the Optimism repository, opening a pull request to introduce a configurable delay between game responses (ethereum-optimism/optimism#16988). This work involved modifying 10 files with +239/-10 lines of changes. The contributions were primarily focused on application code and associated tests.

PowVT: This week, PowVT focused on expanding the superchain ecosystem by proposing the addition of a new testnet. They opened a pull request to add the Sova Sepolia Testnet to the superchain registry (ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry#1094), which involved over 350 lines of changes across 10 files. This work consisted primarily of modifications to configuration and documentation files.

geoknee: This week, geoknee focused on investigating calldata footprint costs, opening a spike pull request in `ethereum-optimism/optimism` (#16970). This exploratory work involved minor changes (+20/-18 lines) primarily to configuration files. They also contributed to collaboration by leaving two comments on other pull requests.

sebastianst: Focused on the `ethereum-optimism/op-geth` repository, where they are working to address a block limit issue. They have an open pull request (`op-geth#655`) that targets a calldata footprint spike.

teddyknox: This week, teddyknox focused on proposing a new specification for block calldata limits in the `ethereum-optimism/specs` repository through the open pull request `specs#746`. Their contribution involved adding 38 lines of code, with the work focused entirely on tests.

cuiweixie: This week's activity centered on a refinement in the `op-service` for the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. They opened a pull request (#16964) to utilize `bytes.Buffer`, which involved a small modification of +9/-8 lines in a single code file.

longhutianjie: Focused on optimization within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, opening a pull request to improve performance in the Kurtosis devnet by using a preallocated slice (optimism#16990).
